title: Acute Ischemic Stroke
icd10: I63.50 (Cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
I63.30 (Cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
I63.40 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of unspecified cerebral artery)
scope: ** Emergency evaluation and treatment of acute ischemic stroke, including thrombolysis decision-making, mechanical thrombectomy candidacy, acute stroke unit care, secondary prevention, and etiologic workup. For hemorrhagic stroke, TIA, or venous sinus thrombosis, use dedicated templates.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can mimic stroke; required before tPA
Anticoagulation status; INR >1.7 contraindication to tPA

Rare/Specialized.item: Antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-beta2 glycoprotein)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Hypercoagulable workup; repeat in 12 weeks if positive

Rare/Specialized.item: Protein C, Protein S, Antithrombin III
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Inherited thrombophilia (defer acute phase; check 2-4 weeks post-stroke)

Rare/Specialized.item: Factor V Leiden, Prothrombin gene mutation
Fabry disease testing (alpha-galactosidase A, GLA gene)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young cryptogenic stroke, especially with other Fabry features

Essential/First-line.timing: STAT - door to CT <25 min target
Essential/First-line.target: No hemorrhage; early ischemic changes (ASPECTS score)

Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate), CKD (benefit usually outweighs risk in acute stroke)

Essential/First-line.timing: If within extended window (6-24 hours) or wake-up stroke
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate), CKD (benefit usually outweighs risk in acute stroke)

Extended.timing: Within 24 hours; better for small/posterior strokes
With MRI if CTA not done

Extended.target: LV thrombus, PFO, valvular disease, wall motion abnormalities

Extended.timing: If TTE non-diagnostic and high suspicion for cardiac source; or PFO evaluation
Extended.target: LAA thrombus, aortic atheroma, PFO with atrial septal aneurysm

Extended.timing: If CTA/MRA not done or for follow-up

Extended.item: Extended cardiac monitoring (Holter 7-30 days or implantable loop recorder)
Extended.timing: Cryptogenic stroke; AF not detected on telemetry

Rare/Specialized.timing: If vasculitis suspected; CNS vasculitis workup
If vasculitis, infectious, or inflammatory etiology suspected
Occult malignancy workup; giant cell arteritis

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 min, remainder over 60 min; within 4.5 hours

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).contraindications: See Appendix A; major: ICH, recent surgery, BP >185/110, INR >1.7, platelets <100K
Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Neuro checks q15min x 2h, then q30min x 6h, then q1h x 16h; BP q15min x 2h; hold anticoagulants 24h

dosing.instructions: 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus (max 25 mg); single bolus (no infusion); within 4.5 hours

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).contraindications: See Appendix A; major: ICH, recent surgery, BP >185/110, INR >1.7, platelets <100K
Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Neuro checks q15min x 2h, then q30min x 6h; BP q15min x 2h; hold anticoagulants 24h

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV over 1-2 min; may repeat or double q10min; max 300 mg; target BP <185/110

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).contraindications: Asthma, severe bradycardia, decompensated HF, 2nd/3rd degree heart block
Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Continuous BP; target BP <185/110 for tPA eligibility

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg/hr IV; increase by 2.5 mg/hr q5-15min; max 15 mg/hr; target BP <185/110
Start 1-2 mg/hr IV; titrate by doubling q90sec initially; max 32 mg/hr

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).contraindications: Soy/egg allergy, severe aortic stenosis, lipid disorders
Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Continuous BP; rapid onset; short half-life

doseOptions.orderSentence: BP management (post-tPA) Labetalol 10-20 mg IV IV
BP management (post-tPA) Nicardipine 5-15 mg/hr IV IV
BP management (post-tPA) Clevidipine 1-32 mg/hr IV IV

dosing.instructions: Labetalol 10-20 mg IV q10min, nicardipine 5-15 mg/hr, or clevidipine 1-32 mg/hr; target BP <180/105 x 24h
dosing.orderSentence: BP management (post-tPA) Labetalol 10-20 mg IV IV

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Continuous BP; target BP <180/105 for 24 hours post-tPA

dosing.instructions: Endovascular clot retrieval; within 6 hours for anterior LVO; up to 24 hours with favorable perfusion imaging

Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).contraindications: Large completed infarct (ASPECTS <6), poor baseline function (mRS >2), no LVO
Acute/Emergent (Hyperacute Phase).monitoring: Post-procedure: BP per protocol, groin site checks, neuro checks q1h

dosing.instructions: NPO until formal swallow screen passed

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV fluids - Normal saline NS 500 mL IV
IV fluids - Normal saline NS 1000 mL IV

dosing.instructions: 0.9% NaCl; avoid dextrose-containing fluids (hyperglycemia worsens outcomes)
dosing.orderSentence: IV fluids - Normal saline NS 500 mL IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin - Glucose management Per protocol IV/SC

dosing.instructions: Sliding scale or infusion; target glucose 140-180 mg/dL; avoid hypoglycemia
dosing.orderSentence: Insulin - Glucose management Per protocol IV/SC

dosing.instructions: Apply to both legs
40 mg SC daily; reduce to 30 mg if CrCl <30; start 24-48h post-stroke if no hemorrhage
5000 units SC q8-12h; alternative to enoxaparin if CrCl <30
650-1000 mg PO/PR q4-6h PRN temp >38C; max 4g/day; target normothermia

doseOptions.orderSentence: Head of bed positioning HOB flat to 15° —

dosing.instructions: Flat to 15° initially if no LVO treated; elevate to 30° if large infarct or aspiration risk
dosing.orderSentence: Head of bed positioning HOB flat to 15° —

dosing.instructions: Titrate to SpO2 >94%; avoid routine oxygen in non-hypoxic patients
Load 325 mg (after tPA, wait 24h, confirm no ICH); Maintenance 81-325 mg daily

dosing.instructions: Load 300-600 mg; Maintenance 75 mg daily

Secondary Prevention (Initiate During Ho.monitoring: Bleeding; discontinue one agent at day 21

dosing.instructions: 40-80 mg daily; start in hospital; high-intensity statin

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg daily; dose adjust for Asian patients, CKD

Secondary Prevention (Initiate During Ho.monitoring: LFTs at baseline; CK if myalgia

dosing.instructions: 20 mg daily with dinner; 15 mg if CrCl 15-50; delay 4-14 days post-stroke

dosing.instructions: 150 mg BID; 75 mg BID if CrCl 15-30; delay 4-14 days post-stroke

Secondary Prevention (Initiate During Ho.monitoring: Renal function; bleeding; reversal agent availability

dosing.instructions: 60 mg daily; 30 mg if CrCl 15-50, weight ≤60 kg, or P-gp inhibitor; delay 4-14 days

dosing.instructions: Start with heparin bridge; target INR 2-3 (2.5-3.5 for mechanical mitral); delay 4-14 days
Start 2.5-5 mg daily; titrate to 20-40 mg daily; target BP <130/80

12.5-25 mg daily

Complications Management.monitoring: Post-op neuro checks, ICP if monitored

Special Situations.contraindications: Active bleeding, large infarct, hemorrhagic transformation
Special Situations.monitoring: PTT q6h until therapeutic, then q12-24h

dosing.instructions: Interventional procedure; typically after stroke recovery; age <60

Special Situations.contraindications: Active infection, other stroke etiology identified
Special Situations.monitoring: Post-procedure: antiplatelet therapy, bubble study follow-up

dosing.instructions: Surgical; timing 2-14 days post-stroke optimal
Interventional procedure; alternative to CEA

Special Situations.contraindications: Unstable medical condition, near-complete occlusion; unfavorable anatomy

Referrals & Consults.indication: AF management, PFO evaluation, cardiac source workup
Large stroke with poor prognosis; goals of care

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new or worsening weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or severe headache
Know stroke warning signs: F.A.S.T. (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911)
Take all prescribed medications as directed; do not stop antiplatelet or anticoagulant without physician guidance
Attend all follow-up appointments (neurology, cardiology, primary care)
No driving until cleared by physician (typically minimum 2-4 weeks; varies by state law and deficit severity)
Report any bleeding (blood in stool, urine, gums, excessive bruising) while on blood thinners
Check blood pressure at home daily if hypertensive; keep log for follow-up visits
Monitor blood glucose if diabetic; maintain good glycemic control
Follow swallow precautions if dysphagia present (diet modification, positioning, supervision)
Use fall precautions: clear pathways, use assistive devices as prescribed, adequate lighting

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (most important modifiable risk factor)
LDL cholesterol target <70 mg/dL (or 50% reduction) with high-intensity statin
Limit alcohol: ≤1 drink/day women, ≤2 drinks/day men; abstinence if alcohol-related stroke
Heart-healthy diet: Mediterranean or DASH diet
Regular aerobic exercise: 40 min moderate-intensity 3-4 days/week when able
Sleep apnea screening and treatment if indicated
Hormone replacement therapy: avoid or use caution

differential.features: Rapid response to glucose; often diabetic on insulin/sulfonylureas
History of seizure; gradual resolution over hours; post-ictal confusion
Headache (usually); positive symptoms (scintillating scotoma); history of similar; <60 min
Sudden severe headache; rapid progression; may have anticoagulation history
Gradual onset; headache; seizures; may have mass effect
History of trauma (may be minor); elderly; anticoagulation
Fever; altered mental status; seizures; behavioral changes
Younger patient; prior episodes; MRI pattern (periventricular, Dawson fingers)
Inconsistent exam; positive functional signs (Hoover, give-way weakness)
Severely elevated BP; headache; confusion; PRES pattern on MRI
Headache; may have hypercoagulable state or OCP use; hemorrhagic infarcts
Confusion, seizures; recent medication change; SIADH
History of substance use; pupils; toxidrome

evidence.recommendation: IV alteplase within 4.5 hours improves outcomes
Mechanical thrombectomy for LVO within 6 hours
Thrombectomy up to 24 hours with favorable imaging
DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) for minor stroke/high-risk TIA x 21 days
Decompressive craniectomy for malignant MCA stroke

monitoring.item: NIHSS (National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale)
monitoring.frequency: Q1h x 24h, then q4h x 48h, then q shift
monitoring.action: If worsening ≥4 points: emergent CT, consider hemorrhage or extension

monitoring.frequency: Q15min x 2h post-tPA, then q30min x 6h, then q1h x 16h; q4h after
Q6h; q1h if on insulin infusion

monitoring.action: Acetaminophen; cooling; infection workup if fever
Oxygen titration; evaluate for aspiration, PE

monitoring.frequency: Daily during hospitalization; baseline for DOACs
24 hours post-tPA; or if neurological decline
monitoring.action: If hemorrhage: reverse anticoagulation, neurosurgery consult

disposition.criteria: Minor stroke or TIA; able to ambulate safely or with minimal assistance; swallow intact; stable on oral medications; adequate home support; follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks; compliant with secondary prevention
Most acute ischemic strokes; requires monitoring, workup, rehabilitation assessment; stable vital signs; no respiratory compromise

Received tPA or thrombectomy (24h monitoring); large vessel occlusion; declining neurological exam; respiratory compromise; malignant edema risk; BP requiring IV infusion; arrhythmia requiring intervention
Significant functional deficits; able to participate in 3 hours therapy/day; medically stable; expected to benefit
Functional deficits; unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; needs skilled nursing care
Prolonged ventilator dependence; complex medical needs
LVO needing thrombectomy not available locally; neurosurgical intervention needed; complex case
